title: Sitting On the Dock of the Bay

musicalLanguage.description: Otis Redding's laid-back masterpiece captures the feeling of watching the tide roll in. Built on a simple G-B7-C-A progression, the song is accessible for beginners while sounding musically complete. The melody is conversational and unhurried, and the left hand plays simple root-position chords.
musicalLanguage.structure: Verse: G-B7-C-A pattern (4 bars), Chorus: E-G-E-G rocking motion (4 bars)
keyMoments: Bar 1: G major opens — relaxed, like sitting on a dock.
Bar 2: B7 — the unexpected major chord on the III. Gives it soul.
Bars 5-6: E minor to G — the rocking motion of the chorus, like waves.
teachingGoals: Simple chord progressions with one unexpected chord (B7)
Relaxed tempo playing — resisting the urge to rush
Basic left hand chord patterns supporting melody
styleTips: Play like you have nowhere to be — this song is about doing nothing
The B7 chord should surprise slightly — bring it out a touch
Left hand: simple and steady. Right hand: conversational and easy

measures.teachingNote: G major — open and easy. The melody settles immediately.
B7 — the soulful twist. F# in the melody leans into this chord.
C major — bright lift. Melody bounces gently.
A major — settling down before the chorus.
E minor — the rocking chorus figure. Back and forth like waves.
G major — still rocking. Keep it effortless.
E minor — the wave continues. Same gentle motion.
G major — fade out. The rest at the end is the sound of the ocean.
